author: By Peter Fairley
title: There Is a Part of Modern Life That Is So Essential Armies Should Never Attack It Again
description: The global community must draw bright lines for combatants in future conflicts by creating specific protections for power grids.
content: In late March, after two years of withering attacks on Ukraine, Russia knocked out half of Ukraine’s power supply. Up to that point, Russia’s missiles and kamikaze drones had mostly targeted the Ukrainian substations that push electricity from power plants to consumers. But this time they hit the plants themselves, severely damaging and destroying hydroelectric and fossil fuel stations — all of which are difficult to repair or replace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Validation for Woman Who Said She Was Raped in Australia’s Parliament
description: More than three years after Brittany Higgins went public with her claim of rape, her case reached a conclusion of sorts.
content: When a young former government employee said on national television in 2021 that she had been sexually assaulted in Australia’s Parliament two years earlier, it shocked the nation and unleashed a wave of anger aimed at the country’s insular, male-dominated political establishment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Kidnapped With 275 Girls, She Finally Escaped
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 15, 2024.
content: “The only crime of these girls was to go to school.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gisela Williams
title: A Beloved Copenhagen Cafe Gets Serious About Dinner
description: The chef Frederik Bille Brahe has transformed the Apollo Bar & Kantine into his version of a fine dining restaurant, and celebrated with a meal for his family and collaborators.
content: When the Danish chef Frederik Bille Brahe took over Apollo Bar & Kantine in 2017, it was an unassuming museum cafe where a person might grab a quick sandwich after seeing one of the contemporary art exhibitions at the Kunsthal Charlottenborg, set within the same grand 17th-century complex in central Copenhagen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Patti Astor, Doyenne of New York’s Avant-Garde Scene, Dies at 74
description: She was a founder of the Fun Gallery, which staged early shows by Keith Haring and other artists who defined the city’s downtown scene in the 1980s.
content: Patti Astor, the downtown Manhattan “It” girl, indie film star and co-founder of Fun Gallery, the scruffy East Village storefront space that in the early 1980s nurtured young graffiti artists like Futura2000, Zephyr, Lee Quinones, Lady Pink and Fab 5 Freddy, as well as showcasing artists like Keith Haring, Kenny Scharf and Jean-Michel Basquiat, died on April 9 at her home in Hermosa Beach, Calif. She was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin and Vivian Nereim
title: With Iran’s Strikes, Arab Countries Fear an Expanding Conflict
description: The Iranian attack on Israeli territory made the Middle East’s new reality undeniable: Clashes are getting harder and harder to contain.
content: Arab countries, from the United Arab Emirates and Oman to Jordan and Egypt, have tried for months to tamp down the conflict between Israel and Hamas, especially after it widened to include armed groups backed by Iran and embedded deep within the Arab world. Some of them, like the Houthis, threaten Arab governments as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher R. Weingarten
title: Rico Wade and Organized Noize’s 10 Essential Songs
description: The producer helped shape and boost the sound of Atlanta rap starting in the mid-1990s. His death at 52 was announced last Saturday.
content: The Atlanta producer Rico Wade was the de facto leader of the Dungeon Family, the loose collective of rappers and musicians that coalesced around his mother’s smoke-filled Georgia basement — a.k.a. the Dungeon — in the mid-90s. Wade’s open doors and nurturing vision became the engine of Atlanta’s creative explosion, tilting the spotlight away from New York and Los Angeles and toward the homegrown sounds of artists like Outkast, Goodie Mob, Killer Mike, Janelle Monáe and eventually Wade’s younger cousin Future. Wade’s death at 52 was announced on social media last Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Severe Storms Expected in the Plains and Midwest
description: Large hail, damaging winds, heavy rain and isolated tornadoes are expected on Monday in the Plains before moving into the Midwest on Tuesday.
content: Thunderstorms, damaging winds and large hail are expected in the Plains starting on Monday before moving across parts of Illinois, Iowa, Missouri, the South and the Midwest, the National Weather Service said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Philharmonic Sidelines 2 Players It Tried to Fire for Misconduct
description: The New York Philharmonic said the musicians would not perform for now, after a magazine article brought new attention to allegations of misconduct. They have denied wrongdoing.
content: The New York Philharmonic said on Monday that two players it had tried to fire in 2018 — but was forced to rehire after the musicians’ union challenged their dismissal — would not take part in rehearsals or performances for the time being after a magazine article detailed the allegations of misconduct that had been made against them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma, Alex Travelli and Uma Bista
title: On Himalayan Hillsides Grows Japan’s Cold, Hard Cash
description: A shrub in impoverished Nepal now supplies the raw material for the bank notes used in Asia’s most sophisticated financial system.
content: The views are spectacular in this corner of eastern Nepal, between the world’s highest mountains and the tea estates of India’s Darjeeling district, where rare orchids grow and red pandas play on the lush hillsides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek
title: What to Know About Jury Selection in Trump’s Manhattan Criminal Case
description: As Donald J. Trump’s prosecution begins, lawyers must winnow a pool of hundreds to 12 jurors who will decide his fate.
content: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Iran’s Strike on Israel Creates Military Uncertainty, Diplomatic Opportunity
description: Analysts feared Iran’s strikes might set off a wider war. But with Israel still weighing its response, the attack’s military and diplomatic consequences have yet to be determined.
content: The enormous salvo of Iranian weapons fired at Israel this weekend turned the countries’ long-running shadow war into a direct confrontation, raising fears that the countries’ old paradigm of trading carefully measured blows had been replaced by something more overt, violent and risky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: A Few Words About Nests
description: They are the signs of life that I look for when spring arrives.
content: Spring is proceeding apace in this yard, despite my worst fears. For 28 of the 29 years that my husband and I have lived in this house, the elderly widow next door mostly shared our commitment to a natural yard. And because her house backed up to a little patch of woods, too, between us we managed to create a miniature wildlife sanctuary. I could sit outside in springtime and hold very still while a tufted titmouse pulled hairs from my head and carried them to her nest in the yard next door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Rotunno
title: 15 Looks That Did the Most at Coachella
description: The music festival had plenty of memorable fashion. Most (but not all) of it was ostentatious.
content: There was no shortage of celebrities onstage last weekend at the first installment of this year’s Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in Southern California, where Doja Cat, Billie Eilish and even Will Smith performed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: One-Pot Tortellini With Prosciutto and Peas Is for Friends
description: Whether in the eating or in the making of Ali Slagle’s springtime supper.
content: I’ve just returned from visiting friends in the French countryside where we cooked together, improvising dinner from whatever looked promising at the market that day. This is my absolute favorite way to cook: in convivial company, riffing with what the season has offered, exchanging inspiration and knowledge as we go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Blackman
title: Can Trump Get a Jury Who Will Give Him a Fair Shake? My Expert Opinion Is Yes, and Here’s Why.
description: The selection process and the can-do attitude of jurors result in a fair jury almost all the time.
content: If Donald Trump has been clear about anything, it is this: “I cannot get a fair trial in New York.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: ‘Access Hollywood’ Tape Won’t Be Played for Jurors in Trump Trial
description: But the judge overseeing Donald J. Trump’s hush-money trial said the jury can be told what he said in the clip, where he bragged about grabbing women’s genitals.
content: The judge in Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial on Monday again refused to allow the infamous “Access Hollywood” tape to be played for jurors, but said that the comments Mr. Trump made on the tape could be introduced as evidence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: To Fight Climate Change, We Need New ‘Political Technologies’
description: Our institutions are bad at solving “long problems,” but they don’t need to be.
content: Science alone won’t stop the planet from overheating. But science coupled with political science just might.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Barry Diller Bets on Media Veterans to Turn Around The Daily Beast
description: The former Disney executive Ben Sherwood and Joanna Coles, the former Hearst content chief, are being given a minority stake in the digital tabloid.
content: The Daily Beast has long been an outlier in the digital empire of the billionaire Barry Diller. As sites like Match.com and Expedia made millions over the years, Mr. Diller’s digital tabloid lost money, publishing scoop after scoop but struggling to turn a profit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Pentagon Reviews Events Before Attack That Killed 13 U.S. Troops in Kabul
description: A team conducted new interviews to address lingering questions about the bombing in the final days of U.S. military involvement in Afghanistan.
content: A new Pentagon review of the events leading up to the bombing that killed 13 American service members at the airport in Kabul, Afghanistan, in August 2021, has reaffirmed earlier findings that U.S. troops could not have prevented the deadly violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: Federal Officials to Shut Women’s Prison After Years of Sexual Abuse
description: About 600 inmates housed at the troubled facility in the San Francisco Bay Area will be transferred to other federal institutions.
content: For years, the women housed at the low-security federal prison in Northern California said they were victims of sexual assault at the hands of staff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuel Marc Gerecht and Ray Takeyh
title: Keeping U.S. Power Behind Israel Will Keep Iran at Bay
description: The best way for Washington to limit the expansion of the Israel-Iran conflict is to clearly signal its intention to support an Israeli counterattack.
content: Until Iran’s barrage of missiles and drones against Israel, the two countries had avoided open military intrusions into each other’s territory. Tehran most often acted through proxies, and Jerusalem via bombing runs and unacknowledged assassinations in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Norman Lear’s Art Goes to Auction
description: The television producer’s prime pieces will be featured in a special evening sale at Christie’s in May.
content: Norman Lear was best known for what he created on television, but he also appreciated the kind of art you can hang on the wall and collected his fair share over the years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Why Better Times (and Big Raises) Haven’t Cured the Inflation Hangover
description: Frustrated by higher prices, many Pennsylvanians with fresh pay raises and solid finances report a sense of insecurity lingering from the pandemic.
content: In western Pennsylvania, halfway through one of those classic hazy March days when the worst of winter has passed, but the bare trees tilting in the wind tell everyone spring is yet to come, Darren Mattern was putting in some extra work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford and Mihir Zaveri
title: New York Nears a Housing Deal to Confront Affordability Crisis
description: The agreement could clear the way for the construction of hundreds of thousands of homes and make it more difficult for landlords to evict renters.
content: New York state leaders have reached a deal on the framework of a legislative plan to address one of the worst housing crises in the nation, Gov. Kathy Hochul said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Britain’s Leaders Condemn Iran’s Attacks but Urge Israel to Show Restraint
description: Rishi Sunak said the government in Tehran was “intent on sowing chaos” in the region, but he also called for restraint from “all sides.”
content: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain on Monday combined a strong condemnation of Iran’s weekend attack on Israel with a call for restraint from “all sides,” adding that he was working with allies to lower tensions in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gisela Williams
title: A Radicchio Salad for People Who Don’t Think They Like Radicchio
description: The Danish chef Frederik Bille Brahe shares the recipe for the star dish at his newly reopened Copenhagen cafe Apollo Bar & Kantine.
content: At the start of this year, the celebrated Danish chef Frederik Bille Brahe, 40, closed down Apollo Bar & Kantine, his beloved art-world hangout in the courtyard of Copenhagen’s Kunsthal Charlottenborg, in order to reinvent the space and its menus. He and his executive chef, Yuta Kurahashi, 36, shifted their focus to dinner and now serve an evening meal of pared-back dishes that riff on seasonal ingredients. But if Bille Brahe likes to keep things simple, he also enjoys surprising his guests. The dish he calls Salada Rosso presents as an untouched head of radicchio but it is, in fact, a clever piece of trompe l’oeil: the chicory has been deconstructed, its bitter leaves coated with a rich, earthy black garlic and almond cream and a sweet citrus vinaigrette, then reassembled with chunks of tart blood orange tucked between them. Radicchio, Bille Brahe says, is a vegetable “most people think they don’t like — but then you make something with it that changes their minds.” Here, he shares the recipe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Transgender Veterans Sue V.A. Over Gender-Affirming Surgeries
description: The lawsuit, brought by the Transgender American Veterans Association, said the Veteran Affairs department’s decision not to offer the procedures was discriminatory.
content: An advocacy group for transgender veterans has filed a lawsuit over the failure of the Department of Veterans Affairs to provide or pay for gender-affirming surgeries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Trump’s Criminal Trial Begins With a Bumpy Jury Selection
description: Also, Israel weighs retaliation against Iran. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: New York prosecutors joined Donald Trump and his attorneys today in a Manhattan courtroom for the official start of the first criminal trial of an American president. Trump is facing 34 felony counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal during his 2016 campaign. If convicted, he could face up to four years in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Owners of Funeral Home With Decaying Bodies Are Charged With Covid Relief Fraud
description: Originally charged after 190 decomposing bodies were found at their Colorado funeral home, the couple now face federal charges that they fraudulently obtained $880,000 in relief funds.
content: A couple arrested last year after at least 190 bodies were found decomposing at their Colorado funeral home were arrested again on Sunday on federal charges that they fraudulently obtained more than $880,000 in pandemic relief money, which they spent on vacations and personal goods, according to the F.B.I. and court records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Atlantic City Mayor Accused of Beating and Punching His Teenage Daughter
description: Marty Small Sr. and his wife, La’Quetta Small, were both charged with endangering the welfare of a child, prosecutors said.
content: The mayor of Atlantic City, N.J., Marty Small Sr., and his wife, La’Quetta Small, the superintendent of Atlantic City’s public schools, have been accused of physically and emotionally abusing their teenage daughter, officials announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Hubbard
title: Three Daughters, Three New Memoirs About Mothers
description: Genevieve Kingston, Susan Lieu and Kao Kalia Yang explore the complicated lives of the women who raised them.
content: Mothers rarely reveal themselves fully to their growing children. Who would it serve, after all, to pull back the curtain on the woman-in-charge and reveal a fumbling human? Like the Wizard of Oz, moms don’t always know how things work, but let’s not scare the kids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: These Gay Novels Offer a ‘More Interesting Conversation’ About Faith
description: Recent books by Allen Bratton, Daniel Lefferts and Garrard Conley depict gay Christian characters not usually seen in queer literature.
content: Near the end of Daniel Lefferts’s recent novel, “Ways and Means,” the protagonist — a gay and ambitious but disastrously wayward college student — takes an unexpected turn for a queer character: He finds salvation in God.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen and Adrienne Grunwald
title: Roses Are Red, Love Is True. Here’s Why This Bouquet Costs $72.
description: A dozen red roses is timeless. But its price tag is not. At Ditmars Flower Shop in Queens, where costs have soared in recent years, a bouquet is $72, up from $60 in 2019.
content: To gather every last stem and ribbon, Mr. Patrikis is on the phone constantly, negotiating with 15 distributors to get the best deals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By W.J. Hennigan
title: The U.S. Has Received a Rare Invitation From China. There Is Only One Right Answer.
description: Should the U.S. forswear launching nukes first in combat?
content: In the middle of the last century, as the United States and Russia rapidly amassed thousands of nuclear weapons, China stayed out of the arms race, focusing its energy on growing its economy and broadening its regional influence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: Chinese Company Under Congressional Scrutiny Makes Key U.S. Drugs
description: Lawmakers raising national security concerns and seeking to disconnect a major Chinese firm from U.S. pharmaceutical interests have rattled the biotech industry. The firm is deeply involved in development and manufacturing of crucial therapies for cancer, cystic fibrosis, H.I.V. and other illnesses.
content: A Chinese company targeted by members of Congress over potential ties to the Chinese government makes blockbuster drugs for the American market that have been hailed as advances in the treatment of cancers, obesity and debilitating illnesses like cystic fibrosis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘The Stranger’ Review: Somewhere Over the Freeway
description: In this tense thriller on Hulu, Maika Monroe plays Clare, a Kansas transplant in Los Angeles who parallels Dorothy in Oz.
content: “The Stranger” is a tense if tidy thriller that chronicles a ride-hail driver’s journey to surveillance hell and back. Her survival against all odds mirrors that of the movie itself: The film’s footage originally premiered in 13 short-form episodes in 2020 on the streaming service Quibi, several months before it shut down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Poised to Cut Back Scope of Anti-Corruption Law
description: The question for the justices was whether a federal law prohibits not only before-the-fact bribes but also after-the-fact rewards.
content: The Supreme Court seemed ready on Monday to limit the reach of a federal statute that makes it a crime for state and local officials, along with institutions that receive federal money, to accept gifts and payments meant to influence or reward their actions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Should I Dress to Hide My Scars or Show Them Off?
description: Scars can be covered up or airbrushed away, our critic writes. But what is lost when we erase our experiences from our bodies?
content: In a world of Instagram filters, Photoshop, fillers, Botox, lasers and every other body treatment under the sun, it can be shocking to look at your actual untouched self. Marks that once signaled a life well lived — or adventurously lived, or dangerously lived, or joyfully lived; of pain experienced and conquered — can now seem a somewhat embarrassing sign of wear and tear, or human frailty. And no one wants to be giving worn-down vibes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín
title: At This Hockey Game, the Biggest Save Might Have Kept a Boy Alive
description: A man deflected a puck heading straight for a boy’s head at a game in Ohio. With the help of TikTok, his mother was reunited with her son’s protector.
content: Asia Davis was up late thinking about the harrowing finish to the hockey game the night before, and decided that she needed to find the man who might have saved her son’s life. So she went on TikTok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: Straws That Don’t Cause Wrinkles. Wait — Straws Cause Wrinkles?
description: Another solution to a problem we didn’t know we had.
content: Maybe it’s the superior experience of sipping a crisp, carbonated beverage through a straw. Maybe it’s the rise of Stanley Cups, or the supremacy of cold brew even in the winter months. Whatever it is, straws have evolved beyond the single-use plastic straw-man argument for environmental personal responsibility into so much more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Jesse McKinley, Adam Rasgon, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and James Shield
title: Picking a Jury to Try Trump, and What’s Next for Iran and Israel
description: Plus, the mortgages keeping people stuck in their homes.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Chang W. Lee
title: Four Wild Ways to Save the Koala (That Just Might Work)
description: To protect Australia’s iconic animals, scientists are experimenting with vaccine implants, probiotics, tree-planting drones and solar-powered tracking tags.
content: It was spring in Queensland, Australia, a season when many wild animals find themselves in trouble, and the Currumbin Wildlife Hospital was a blur of fur and feathers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: We’re Adding to Our California Movie List
description: “Harold and Maude,” “The Grapes of Wrath” and more.
content: Because of reader recommendations, I recently had the pleasure of watching for the first time “Boyz N the Hood,” the 1991 coming-of-age story set in South Central Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rollo Romig
title: A Video Game Made Out of Brick, Clay and Tenacity
description: The handcrafted Harold Halibut, about a hapless janitor stuck in an undersea city, was more than a decade in the making.
content: A handmade video game sounds like an oxymoron, like a rock opera or a TV movie. But on rare occasions, designers choose to build their interactive worlds not from pixels and polygons but from physical materials like cardboard and clay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: What Elective Do You Wish Your School Offered?
description: A program at a high school in Missouri teaches students how to bring food from the farm to the table. What nontraditional classes would you like to take?
content: Does your school offer elective classes? Have you taken any? If so, which have been your favorite? Why?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: ‘Rust’ Armorer Is Sentenced to 18 Months for Involuntary Manslaughter
description: The armorer, Hannah Gutierrez-Reed, got the maximum sentence for loading a live round into a gun on a film set, leading to the death of Halyna Hutchins, the movie’s cinematographer.
content: The armorer on the film “Rust,” who loaded a live round into a revolver that went off on the set in 2021 and killed its cinematographer, was sentenced on Monday to 18 months in prison for involuntary manslaughter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: Prosecutors’ Error Exposes Potential Scope of Disgraced Detective’s Harm
description: The Brooklyn district attorney’s office didn’t mean to send opposing lawyers an unredacted file about Louis Scarcella, a former N.Y.P.D. detective whose overturned cases have cost New York millions.
content: In court papers they are called the “Scarcella Lists” — compilations of cases involving a retired New York City homicide detective whose problematic work on homicides in the 1980s and 1990s was cited in numerous wrongful convictions that have cost the city and state millions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA Seeks ‘Hail Mary’ for Its Mars Rocks Return Mission
description: The agency will seek new ideas for its Mars Sample Return program, expected to be billions of dollars over budget and years behind schedule.
content: The cost of a proposed NASA mission to gather rocks on Mars and return them to Earth is spiraling upward and slipping further into the future. So on Monday, space agency officials asked for ideas on simplifying the mission and trimming its price tag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Thomas
title: Beyond Pizza and Yale: What to See, Eat and Do in New Haven
description: Though the academic scene continues to imbue this coastal Connecticut city with a certain gravitas, surrounding neighborhoods are showing off their own cultural capital in the realms of art, food, music and more.
content: The 75-foot-long brontosaurus at the newly reopened Yale Peabody Museum in New Haven, Conn., is the same dinosaur that the natural history museum has had on display since 1931. Yet it looks different. A fresh pose. New front ribs. The head is repositioned at a more inquisitive angle. The museum’s four-year renovation not only refreshed the nearly 100-year-old building, but also included an overhaul of the fossil mounts that research has proved to be inaccurate.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Donald Trump on Trial: What to Expect
description: Readers discuss what’s at stake, the jurors and the possibility of Donald Trump’s testifying. Also: Aid to Ukraine; originalism; thinking rationally.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Rosenwald
title: Robert Beerbohm, Pioneering Comic Book Retailer and Historian, Dies at 71
description: A professed archaeologist of the industry, he opened his own stores and partnered with other experts and vendors in the nascent comics business.
content: Robert Beerbohm, who in the 1970s helped start the first comic book chain stores and then, after a flood wiped out inventory in his warehouse, became a professed archaeologist of comics history, died on March 27 at his home in Fremont, Neb. He was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Want to Win at Solitaire? Players Share Their Best Tips
description: Nine strategies that will improve your odds of winning.
content: In some countries, one of the many variants of Solitaire games is called Patience, and it’s an apt name. If this pastime teaches you anything, it’s how to keep from losing your cool while you cycle through the deck looking for that red six.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Reeling From Mass Stabbing, Australians Ask: Was It About Hatred of Women?
description: All but three of the 18 people killed or injured Saturday were women. While the attacker’s motive may never be known, many said the episode spoke to a larger problem.
content: Mary Aravanopoulos stood clutching her daughter, huddling for safety with about 15 other women in the dress shop filled with ethereal organza gowns. They had watched a man saunter past in the mall corridor, swinging a large knife in his hand back and forth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellina Moore
title: What’s on TV This Week: The WNBA Draft and ‘RuPaul’s Drag Race’
description: The highly anticipated draft for professional women’s basketball airs on ESPN. The 16th season of RuPaul’s Emmy-winning competition series concludes on MTV.
content: For those who still haven’t cut the cord, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, April 15-21. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: Why Your Big Sister Resents You
description: “Eldest daughter syndrome” assumes that birth order shapes who we are and how we interact. Does it?
content: In a TikTok video that has been watched more than 6 million times, Kati Morton, a licensed marriage and family therapist in Santa Monica, Calif., lists signs that she says can be indicative of “eldest daughter syndrome.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Donald Trump, the Defendant
description: Trump has tried to project strength and confidence around his New York trial, but it might not be easy.
content: He scoffed. He slumped. He seemed to sleep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Flying With Dogs or Cats? These Are Airlines’ Pet Policies
description: American recently relaxed its rules for pets traveling inside the cabin with their owners. Here’s what the major U.S. airlines require to travel with a pet.
content: Flying with a pet can be expensive and confusing, with fees, weight limits, carrier size rules and the need to make sure there’s no loud barking (or meowing) on board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Shteamer
title: How the Trumpeter Jeremy Pelt Became a Chronicler of Black Jazz History
description: Inspired by the drummer Arthur Taylor’s “Notes and Tones” collection of interviews with fellow musicians, Pelt started his own book series, “Griot.”
content: The trumpeter Jeremy Pelt was sitting on his couch, browsing YouTube, when he decided to become an author.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.8 Million Homes in California
description: A three-bedroom house in Calistoga, a Cape Cod-style home in Long Beach and a 1927 cottage in Mill Valley.
content: In the late 1860s, Calistoga became a popular vacation destination for residents of San Francisco drawn by the fresh air and natural hot springs. Those hot springs and the surrounding resorts are still a draw, along with the area’s wineries and the hiking trails in Robert Louis Stevenson State Park, which ascend to the top of Mount Saint Helena, about 40 minutes from this property.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caoilinn Hughes
title: Politics Are Always Personal. In This Novel They’re Ruinous.
description: “The Spoiled Heart,” by Sunjeev Sahota, contrasts race and class struggles in the story of a man’s downfall.
content: The titular spoiled heart of Sunjeev Sahota’s new novel is not spoiled in the sense of being overindulged. It is spoiled in the sense of being ruptured, through hardship. A tragedy in which a man comes to personal and profession ruin, the novel explores whether the ruination is self-inflicted or societal, and whether it is a degenerative condition or if some radical surgery can reverse it. Certainly, Sahota has a surgeon’s dexterous hands, and the reader senses his confidence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: At Milan Design Week, the Power Is Often in the Collection
description: The annual festival of furnishings and household objects allows for expressing ideas through design.
content: Milan Design Week, which runs through Sunday, allows companies, collectives or designers to express a unified point of view that transcends the attractions of any single product. All the hand-carved furnishings shown by Zanat, a company in Bosnia and Herzegovina, for example, reflect a dedication to craft that the owners inherited from generations of woodworking family members, though different international designers contributed to the group. This is just one of many examples found through the festival of collections augmenting the messages of their parts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: The Trump Trial: A Monumental Moment
description: With Donald J. Trump expected in court today to face criminal charges, we are entering uncharted territory, our criminal justice reporter says.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday, and we’ll look at the kickoff of Donald Trump’s trial in Lower Manhattan and what it may be like to cover the proceeding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger and Francesca Paris
title: A Huge Number of Homeowners Have Mortgage Rates Too Good to Give Up
description: On a scale not seen in decades, many Americans are stuck in homes they would rather leave.
content: Something deeply unusual has happened in the American housing market over the last two years, as mortgage rates have risen to around 7 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Making Art From the Unexpected at Milan Design Week
description: Designers are showing off some of their latest works at the annual festival of furnishings and household objects.
content: Designers are by definition manipulators — of materials, senses and expectations. There is nothing they like better than making the beholders of their creations stop in their tracks. At the Salone del Mobile, in a show devoted to emerging designers that runs through Sunday, visitors may be arrested by a cushion that resembles a big colorful, softball and sits like an egg in a nest of polished wood sticks. What is it? An ottoman, naturally. A few other eye catchers and head scratchers are presented below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Trump’s Nostalgia Bump
description: Like other former presidents, time has improved Trump’s standing among voters.
content: President Trump left office wildly unpopular. But in the past few years, some voters’ opinions about him have improved. Support for how Trump handled key issues as president — including the economy, and law and order — has risen by about six percentage points since 2020, according to the latest New York Times/Siena College poll. A plurality of voters, 42 percent, now say the Trump years were “mostly good” for the country. Only a quarter say the same of President Biden’s tenure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Park Rangers Search for 2 Vandals Who Toppled Ancient Rocks at Lake Mead
description: After a video was widely shared online of two men pushing over a rock formation at Lake Mead National Recreation Area in Nevada, the authorities are asking for the public’s help to identify them.
content: The National Park Service is seeking help from the public to find two men who were captured on camera toppling an ancient natural rock formation at Lake Mead National Recreation Area in Nevada last week, officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Roberta Karmel, First Woman Named to the S.E.C., Dies at 86
description: She got her training as a young lawyer for the Securities and Exchange Commission, but once she became a commissioner, she accused colleagues of arrogance and insularity.
content: Roberta Karmel, the first female member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, whose belief that the agency stymied legitimate business activities inspired philosophical combat with her colleagues, died on March 23 at her home in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. She was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Tuesday Briefing: Donald Trump’s Trial Begins
description: Also, Israel weighs a response to Iran and Sudan marks a year of war.
content: Jury selection began yesterday in New York City, where Donald Trump faces charges that he falsified business records to cover up a sex scandal while serving as president. It is the first criminal trial of a former U.S. president, and the first of four indictments that Trump faces in the coming months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim and Claire Moses
title: Stabbing of Bishop in Australia During Livestreamed Service Was Act of Terror, Police Say
description: A 15-year-old boy has been arrested in the attack, in which several people were injured. An official said the episode appeared to have been motivated by religious extremism.
content: A stabbing at a church in a suburb of Sydney, Australia, that left several people injured and unfolded during a livestreamed Mass was an act of terrorism, the authorities said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leigh-Ann Jackson
title: ‘A Different World’ Hits the Road to Help Historically Black Colleges
description: The beloved series was set at a fictional historically Black university. Now, cast members have reunited to visit and support real-life schools.
content: Picture a pampered socialite ostentatiously putting her generational wealth on display. Or an outspoken teenage activist leading a climate change protest. Or a charismatic opportunist luring people into his latest scam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: James Dean, Founding Director of NASA Art Program, Dies at 92
description: He arranged for artists to have access to astronauts, launchpads and more. “Their imaginations enable them to venture beyond a scientific explanation,” he once said.
content: James Dean, a landscape painter who ran a NASA program that invited artists like Robert Rauschenberg, Norman Rockwell and Jamie Wyeth to document aspects of the Mercury, Gemini and Apollo projects, died on March 22 in Washington. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: How to Advocate for Yourself at the Dentist
description: To get the best care, experts recommend speaking up. Here are tips for what to ask and how to evaluate the treatments you are offered.
content: Think about the last time you went to a dentist: Did you walk out feeling like your questions were answered, or did you wonder whether your provider was being straight with you?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Lydia DePillis
title: New Migrants Get Work Permits. Other Undocumented Immigrants Want Them, Too.
description: Long-term undocumented immigrants — and their employers — are feeling left out by Biden administration policies allowing most who just crossed the border to work legally.
content: Sam Sanchez, a Chicago restaurateur, was incensed when President Biden announced last September that his administration would extend work eligibility to nearly half a million Venezuelans, many of them migrants who had recently crossed the border illegally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: David Egilman, Doctor Who Took On Drug Companies, Dies at 71
description: His testimony as an expert witness in some 600 trials helped plaintiffs win billions of dollars in cases involving malfeasance by pharmaceutical makers.
content: Dr. David Egilman, a physician and expert witness who, over a 35-year span, gave testimony in some 600 trials involving corporate malfeasance, resulting in billions of dollars in awards for victims and their survivors, died on April 2 at his home in Foxborough, Mass. He was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno and Karl Russell
title: E.V. Sales Are Slowing. Tesla’s Are Slumping.
description: More competition and flagging demand for electric vehicles has led to declining sales at Tesla.
content: As sales of Teslas drop and demand for electric vehicles cools — even as more models enter the market — an increasing number of automakers are competing for a slice of a shrinking pie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: Faith Ringgold Perfectly Captured the Pitch of America’s Madness
description: Ringgold’s landmark career was long ignored by the art establishment. But she kept going, mixing the personal and political, and a late surge of attention rightly put her smack in the middle of MoMA.
content: Faith Ringgold, who died Saturday at 93, was an artist of protean inventiveness. Painter, sculptor, weaver, performer, writer and social justice activist, she made work in which the personal and political were tightly bonded. And much of that work gained popularity among audiences that didn’t necessarily frequent galleries and museums. This was particularly true of her series of semi-autobiographical painted narrative quilts depicting scenes of African American urban childhood, subject matter that translated readily into illustrated children’s books, of which, over the years, Ringgold published many.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Questions About Assassinations Test the Limits of Trump’s Immunity Claim
description: Three Supreme Court briefs from former military leaders and intelligence officials explore whether presidents may be prosecuted for ordering unlawful killings.
content: “It is clear that as president, I will be bound by laws just like all Americans,” Donald J. Trump said in 2016, during his first campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: A Weary Trump Appears to Doze Off in Courtroom Ahead of Criminal Trial
description: The former president flashed signs of irritation at times, but also seemed to fall asleep, before jolting back awake.
content: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle and Damon Winter
title: What I Found Inside the MAGAverse on the Eve of Trump’s Trial
description: Rallying the faithful in the political battleground of eastern Pennsylvania, the former president made everyone else the bad guy.
content: On Saturday afternoon I drove out to eastern Pennsylvania, one of the big battlegrounds between President Biden and Donald Trump in this election, to attend Mr. Trump’s final rally before his criminal trial starts Monday. I was curious about the mood of Trump voters as this historic case gets underway. Were they feeling angry? Worried? Frustrated? Ready to go all civil war?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: At Harlem Stage, Bringing Downtown Dance Uptown
description: As Harlem Stage’s E-Moves dance series turns 25, Bill T. Jones and other major choreographers discuss its impact on Black dance in New York.
content: Since the inception of Harlem Stage’s dance series E-Moves 25 years ago, that “E” has stood for several categories of artists: Emerging. Evolving. Established. But the series itself has always stood for one goal in particular: providing space and resources for artists of color to develop their work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Jones
title: Online Dating After 50 Can Be Miserable. But It’s Also Liberating.
description: You know so much more about yourself and your desires when you’re older that dating apps — even with all their frustrations — can bring unanticipated pleasure.
content: When my marriage collapsed after 23 years, I was devastated and overwhelmed. I was in my 50s, with two jobs, two teenage daughters, one dog. I didn’t consider dating. I had no time, no emotional energy. But then a year passed. One daughter was off at college, the other increasingly independent. After several more months went by, I started to feel a sliver of curiosity about what kind of men were out there and how it would feel to date again. The last time I dated was 25 years ago, and even then, I fell into relationships mostly with guys from high school, college, parties, work. Now every man I knew was either married, too young, too old or otherwise not a good fit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Pang, Priya Krishna and Brian Gallagher
title: The 25 Best Restaurants in Boston Right Now
description: It’s not just seafood and Italian. There’s great Vietnamese, omakase, Peruvian and even bagels worth seeking out. (Don’t worry, there’s also great seafood and Italian.) We’ll see you in the comments.
content: In the Where to Eat: 25 Best series, we’re highlighting our favorite restaurants in cities across the United States. These lists will be updated as restaurants close and open, and as we find new gems to recommend. As always, we pay for all of our meals and don’t accept free items.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Jonah E. Bromwich and William K. Rashbaum
title: Judge in Trump’s Criminal Trial Declines to Recuse Himself
description: Donald J. Trump’s lawyers had called on Justice Juan M. Merchan to remove himself from the case, citing his daughter’s work as a Democratic consultant. Ethics experts had dismissed the idea that the judge was compromised.
content: Juan M. Merchan, the judge overseeing Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial in Manhattan, has declined to step aside from the case, rejecting the former president’s effort to delay the trial and attack his integrity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: After Iran’s Barrage, Israel Questions What Might Be Next for the Gaza War
description: Military analysts are divided on whether a more direct confrontation with Iran might alter the war or affect a decision to invade the southern city of Rafah.
content: Within moments of Israel and its allies shooting down a fusillade of Iranian missiles and drones this weekend, many began wondering what the latest exchange between Israel and Iran would mean for the war in the Gaza Strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 309
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Israel’s Allies Make a Full-Court Press to Urge Restraint
description: Some far-right members of the Israeli government called for a strong response to an Iranian attack, but the U.S., the E.U. and others cautioned against further escalation.
content: Israel’s allies on Monday were strongly urging it not to retaliate against Iran for the missile and drone attack over the weekend, calling instead for a de-escalation of the tensions that have gripped the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: April 15, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 15, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: The Widest-Ever Global Coral Crisis Will Hit Within Weeks, Scientists Say
description: Rising sea temperatures around the planet have caused a bleaching event that is expected to be the most extensive on record.
content: The world’s coral reefs are in the throes of a global bleaching event caused by extraordinary ocean temperatures, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and international partners announced Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Houman Barekat, Matt Wolf and Alex Marshall
title: The Snubs and Surprises of the 2024 Olivier Awards
description: Our theater critics and a reporter discuss the big winner — “Sunset Boulevard” — and the rest of the honorees at Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys.
content: On Sunday night, the Olivier Awards — Britain’s equivalent to the Tonys — took place in London. As expected, “Sunset Boulevard” took home the most trophies (and will have a Broadway run later this year), but there were also some surprise winners. Matt Wolf and Houman Barekat, The New York Times’s London theater critics, joined the reporter Alex Marshall to discuss the winners, the snubs and the last year in British theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Ben Protess, Maggie Haberman and Kate Christobek
title: Prospective Jurors Are Dismissed in Dozens as Trump’s Trial Begins
description: Jury selection began in the Manhattan criminal case, but many who might weigh Donald J. Trump’s fate told a judge that they could not be impartial.
content: Follow today’s live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Kate Christobek
title: Day 1 of Trump’s Criminal Trial: Five Takeaways
description: The former president faces felony charges of falsifying business records to cover up a sexual scandal involving a porn star.
content: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: In City Ballet’s Coming Season, New Works and Earlier Curtain Times
description: New York City Ballet will present a mix of old and new works, including premieres by Justin Peck, Alexei Ratmansky and Caili Quan, and introduce fewer intermissions.
content: New York City Ballet’s 2024-25 season will feature earlier curtain times, fewer intermissions and a tribute to the great American ballerina Maria Tallchief, the company announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: Al Gore Thinks Trump Will Lose and Climate Activists Will Triumph
description: Mr. Gore spoke at a climate leadership conference hosted by his nonprofit organization.
content: Former Vice President Al Gore was in New York City over the weekend for a leadership training convened by the Climate Reality Project, his nonprofit organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Eric Schmitt, Rachelle Bonja, Alex Stern, Luke Vander Ploeg, Marc Georges, Lisa Chow, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop, Corey Schreppel and Chris Wood
title: Iran’s Unprecedented Attack on Israel
description: A yearslong shadow war between the countries burst into the open after Tehran fired hundreds of drones and missiles.
content: Overnight on Saturday, Iran launched its first direct attack on Israeli soil, shooting hundreds of missiles and drones at multiple targets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: What’s Killing Endangered Sawfish in Florida?
description: First, fish off the Florida Keys started swimming in spirals or upside down. Then, endangered sawfish started dying. Scientists are racing to figure out why.
content: Fishing guides in the Florida Keys began reporting unusual sightings to Ross Boucek last fall. Small bait fish, especially at night, would start spinning in tight circles in the water, seemingly in distress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Monday Briefing
description: After Iran’s attack, Israel weighs its options.
content: Israel showed signs that it would not immediately retaliate for the hundreds of exploding drones and missiles that Iran fired at it over the weekend, nearly all of which Israel and its allies intercepted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: A Historic Day
description: Trump arrived this morning at Criminal Court in Lower Manhattan, as jury selection began in the first criminal trial of a former president.
content: A year after Donald Trump was indicted, and after months of legal skirmishes and a torrent of attacks directed at key players in his case, the former president went on trial today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: Expert Panel Calls on Germany to Legalize Abortion in First 12 Weeks
description: For decades, Germany allowed early abortions even while keeping them illegal. A government-appointed commission says the system is “untenable.”
content: A government-appointed commission in Germany recommended on Monday that lawmakers legalize abortion during the first trimester of pregnancy, a move that could push the country into a long-avoided debate on an issue that for decades remained in a legal gray zone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel’s Choices on Response to Iran’s Attack All Come With Risks
description: Its options range from striking Iran openly and forcefully to doing nothing at all. One factor to weigh is that the huge aerial attack did little damage.
content: As Israel’s leaders continued on Monday to mull a possible response to the massive Iranian aerial attack over the weekend, they faced several choices, all of which carry their own risks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman
title: In the 2024 Race, Trump’s Trial Is About to Take Center Stage
description: The race for president will shift much of its focus to a Manhattan courtroom. “This looks like no other presidential campaign in the history of the country,” one Republican pollster said.
content: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: A Slimmer Goldman Sachs Posts Hefty Jump in Profit
description: The Wall Street bank recorded nearly $4 billion in profit, beating analyst expectations in a tough quarter for big banks.
content: What a difference a year makes at Goldman Sachs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Ukraine Sees ‘Hypocrisy’ in Western Allies’ Defense of Israel
description: The U.S., British and French militaries helped intercept Iranian missiles and drones, but Ukrainians say they haven’t provided the same help against Russian air attacks.
content: For people in eastern Ukraine, where nightly barrages of drones from Russia outpace the military’s overwhelmed air defenses, the response by Western allies to Iran’s aerial assault against Israel this weekend produced uncomfortable comparisons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chloe Rose Stuart-Ulin
title: A Surprising Shadow Was Created by the Total Solar Eclipse
description: An ascending jet’s contrail over Montreal added to the wonder of last Monday’s eclipse.
content: Viewers of last week’s solar eclipse were treated to stunning celestial phenomena up and down the event’s path during totality. But those who watched it from Montreal saw a pair of additional surprises in the half-hour before and after the eclipse, when the moon obstructed the sun on April 8.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young and Michael Wilson
title: 2 Police Officers Are Killed in Shootout Near Syracuse, New York
description: A suspect fired at the officers on Sunday evening as they investigated a stolen vehicle in the upstate town of Salina, the authorities said. The suspect died in the shootout.
content: Two police officers, who had been following up on a traffic violation, were killed in a shooting ambush on Sunday evening outside a house in an upstate New York town near Syracuse, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: It’s No Sunday in the Park With ‘Lempicka’
description: A musical about the groundbreaking Art Deco painter is vocally thrilling but historically a blur.
content: Having dismissed her work as merely decorative, a fierce Italian gives harsh advice to an ambitious young painter: “You need to be a monster,” he brays. “Or a machine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Taking a Moment to Lounge at Milan Design Week
description: You can always see where you would like to sit at the annual festival of furnishings and household objects.
content: A cruel irony of Milan Design Week, which runs until Sunday, is that it requires tremendous exertion; visitors must speed walk from booth to booth, and from showroom to showroom, if they hope to see even a fraction of the goods around town. And yet many compelling new products, like the chair, sofas and bed linens presented below, are about rest and relaxation. On the positive side, one usually can take a moment to sink into the displays to see just how comfortable they are. Ahh!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Oil Markets Shrug Off Iran’s Attack on Israel
description: Investors are taking a wait-and-see approach after the much-anticipated aerial assault had little effect on oil supplies.
content: Oil markets shrugged off the growing tensions in the Middle East, after Iran launched a barrage of missiles and drones against Israel over the weekend. On Monday morning, prices for Brent crude oil, the international benchmark, fell by about 1 percent, to $89.49 a barrel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Supreme Court Clears Way, for Now, for Idaho to Ban Transgender Treatment for Minors
description: The Idaho attorney general had asked the justices to move swiftly to let the state law, which would ban gender-affirming medical care for minors, go into effect.
content: The Supreme Court temporarily allowed Idaho on Monday to enforce a ban on gender-affirming treatment for minors, effectively suggesting that some justices appear comfortable with wading into another front in the culture wars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Tesla Will Lay Off More Than 10% of Workers
description: Along with the departure of two senior executives, the cuts added to signs of turmoil at the electric car company.
content: Signs of turmoil at Tesla multiplied on Monday after the electric car company told employees it would lay off more than 10 percent of the work force to cut costs and two senior executives resigned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Aaron Boxerman
title: Here are the latest developments.
description: Israel’s war cabinet met again on Monday as it faced growing international pressure not to retaliate against Iran for its missile and drone attack over the weekend, even as some far-right members of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government called for an aggressive response.
content: Israel’s war cabinet met again on Monday as it faced growing international pressure not to retaliate against Iran for its missile and drone attack over the weekend, even as some far-right members of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government called for an aggressive response.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Biden and His Allies Are Likely to Stay Quiet on Trump’s Manhattan Trial
description: The president’s campaign and other Democrats believe that the court proceedings will do their work for them and that messaging should focus on Mr. Biden’s record.
content: As former President Donald J. Trump goes on trial on Monday in Manhattan, President Biden and his allies are not likely to say much.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and Mike Isaac
title: Ready for a Chatbot Version of Your Favorite Instagram Influencers?
description: Instagram is testing a program that offers its top influencers the ability to interact with their followers over direct messages using a chatbot.
content: Being an influencer can be a lot of work. Instagram thinks A.I. can lend a big hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Salman Rushdie Reflects on His Stabbing in a New Memoir
description: “Knife” is an account of the writer’s brush with death in 2022, and the long recovery that followed.
content: “So it’s you,” Salman Rushdie remembers thinking on the morning of Aug. 12, 2022, as a black-clad man, a “squat missile,” sprinted toward him on an auditorium stage in Chautauqua, N.Y. Rushdie thought: “Here you are.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: What Do You Want to Know About Trump’s Trial in New York?
description: We’ll help answer your questions.
content: The case against Donald Trump in New York is tawdry, consequential and deeply confusing. There are 34 complicated charges. A cast of notorious witnesses. Some extraordinary political implications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Israeli Settlers Kill 2 Palestinian Men in the West Bank, Officials Say
description: The Israeli military said the men were killed during a “violent exchange” that followed a report of a Palestinian attacking an Israeli shepherd.
content: Israeli settlers fatally shot two Palestinians in the West Bank on Monday, according to Israeli and Palestinian officials, as tensions continued to spike in the Israeli-occupied territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Winn
title: The Sex Lives and War Deaths of Soldier Poets
description: In “Muse of Fire,” Michael Korda depicts the lives and passions of the soldier poets whose verse provided a view into the carnage of World War I.
content: It is chillingly plain that the young, fashionable English poet Rupert Brooke had romanticized the great bloodletting that was about to happen. “Come and die,” he wrote to a friend in 1915, during the first winter of World War I. “It will be great fun.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: NPR C.E.O. Faces Criticism Over Tweets Supporting Progressive Causes
description: Katherine Maher, who took over the public network last month, posted years ago on Twitter that “Donald Trump is a racist.”
content: Katherine Maher, the chief executive of NPR, is facing online criticism for years-old social media posts criticizing former President Donald J. Trump and embracing liberal causes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Hochul Announces $237 Billion Budget, Including a Housing Deal
description: The spending plan, which still needs to be approved by the full State Legislature, includes measures on criminal justice, education and illegal cannabis shops.
content: New York State leaders have agreed on the outline of a $237 billion state budget that includes a sweeping package aimed at stemming one of the worst housing shortages in the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Ushio Amagatsu, Japanese Dancer Who Popularized Butoh, Dies at 74
description: He brought worldwide attention to a radical yet elemental form of contemporary dance that emerged in the wake of wartime destruction.
content: Ushio Amagatsu, an acclaimed dancer and choreographer who brought worldwide visibility to Butoh, a hauntingly minimalist Japanese form of dance theater that arose in the wake of wartime devastation, died on March 25 in Odawara, Japan. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: The Biden Guide to Dressing Younger
description: Though much has been made of the president’s age, his tailoring tells another story. There are lessons to be learned here.
content: Joe Biden is a dapper guy. He always has been. When he turned up decades ago for a first date with the woman who would become his wife and the country’s first lady, her gut reaction was, “This is never going to work, not in a million years.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Bidens Report Earning $620,000 and Paying $181,000 in Taxes in 2023
description: The couple’s tax return showed a 7 percent jump in income from 2022, a result of higher taxable interest income this year.
content: President Biden and Jill Biden, the first lady, reported earning roughly $620,000 in 2023, releasing their joint tax return for the third straight year of Mr. Biden’s presidency and the 26th time throughout his political career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: With Nuclear Deal Dead, Containing Iran Grows More Fraught
description: The U.S., Europe, Russia and China worked together on a 2015 deal to limit Iran’s nuclear program. The arrangement’s unraveling and the spike in superpower tensions make this a dangerous moment.
content: When Iran agreed to a deal in 2015 that would require it to surrender 97 percent of the uranium it could use to make nuclear bombs, Russia and China worked alongside the United States and Europe to get the pact done.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: How to Make Frozen Shrimp Even Faster (and More Delicious)
description: You’re 20 minutes and a few simple steps from a fresh spring stir-fry built from a freezer staple.
content: My cousins and I used to dare one another to touch the shrimp, their 10 legs dancing, their antennae waving. At the Chinese seafood restaurants near us in the San Gabriel Valley of Southern California, the servers would bring our orders, still alive, to the table for approval before taking them into the kitchen. In Cantonese cuisine, feisty fish and crustaceans are prized for their delicate freshness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: foolhardy
description: This word has appeared in 26 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word foolhardy has appeared in 26 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 31 in the book review “All That Glitters: A Fresh Look at the California Gold Rush” by W. M. Akers:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Ali Watkins
title: Families of Manchester Bombing Victims File Lawsuit Against MI5
description: The suit comes after an independent public inquiry said the 2017 bombing at an Ariana Grande concert was a “significant missed opportunity” for the U.K. spy agency.
content: Hundreds of survivors of the 2017 Manchester Arena bombing attack have filed a lawsuit against the British government intelligence agency MI5, their lawyers said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Farnaz Fassihi, Aaron Boxerman, Patrick Kingsley and Eric Schmitt
title: A Show of Might in the Skies Over Israel
description: Iran’s retaliation for Israel’s killing of senior military leaders was a highly choreographed spectacle. But fears of a wider war still loom.
content: Iran’s much-anticipated retaliation for Israel’s killing of senior military leaders produced a fiery aerial display in the skies over Israel and the West Bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo and Don Clark
title: U.S. Awards Samsung $6.4 Billion to Bolster Semiconductor Production
description: The federal grants will support Samsung’s new chip manufacturing hub in Taylor, Texas, along with the expansion of an existing site in Austin.
content: The Biden administration will give up to $6.4 billion in grants to Samsung, one of the world’s largest chipmakers, the latest in a slew of awards intended to shore up domestic production of cutting-edge semiconductors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: Lebanese Official Blames Israel’s Spy Agency for Killing Near Beirut
description: The U.S. had accused the dead man of being a financial middleman between Hamas and Iran. The interior minister said there were suggestions that the killing “was carried out by intelligence services.”
content: A Lebanese money changer hit with U.S. sanctions over his alleged role as a financial middleman between Hamas and Iran was found shot to death at a villa just outside Beirut, Lebanon’s state news agency reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: Far Right’s Ties to Russia Sow Rising Alarm in Germany
description: As cases proliferate, opponents fear the Alternative for Germany party is becoming a tool of Russian influence operations to undermine support for Ukraine.
content: To enter a secret session of Germany’s Parliament, lawmakers must lock their phones and leave them outside. Inside, they are not even allowed to take notes. Yet to many politicians, these precautions against espionage now feel like something of a farce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: A.I. Has a Measurement Problem
description: Which A.I. system writes the best computer code or generates the most realistic image? Right now, there’s no easy way to answer those questions.
content: There’s a problem with leading artificial intelligence tools like ChatGPT, Gemini and Claude: We don’t really know how smart they are.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: A Beyoncé Album Repeats at No. 1 for the First Time in 11 Years
description: “Cowboy Carter” tops the Billboard 200 for a second week, boosted by physical sales of her album on CD and vinyl.
content: Beyoncé’s “Cowboy Carter” holds at No. 1 for a second week on the Billboard album chart, fending off new releases from J. Cole and the K-pop group Tomorrow X Together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samantha Maldonado
title: The Fever Dream of Landing an Apartment
description: A woman with a young son started looking for a place before her lease expired, but even her most far-fetched solutions — Buy an RV? — haven’t panned out.
content: Felicia Russo says her friends tell her she seems calm. But she says she’s freaking out on the inside: Her housing search is keeping her up at night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Maerkle
title: Match Made in Venice: Tadao Ando and Zeng Fanzhi
description: From Japan, Ando designed an exhibition for Zeng, the Chinese painter, which generates a sense of surprise and discovery — what LACMA’s director calls “a strange, poetic thing.”
content: An American institution sponsors an exhibition by a Chinese artist in collaboration with a Japanese architect at a centuries-old Venetian building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson, Kayla Guo and Carl Hulse
title: Johnson Says House Will Vote on Stalled Aid to Israel and Ukraine
description: The speaker, who has delayed for months amid G.O.P. opposition to funding for Kyiv, said he would bring up foreign aid legislation along with a bill aimed at appeasing Republican skeptics.
content: Speaker Mike Johnson on Monday said he planned this week to advance a long-stalled national security spending package to aid Israel, Ukraine and other American allies, along with a separate bill aimed at mollifying conservatives who have been vehemently opposed to backing Kyiv.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Markets Brace for Israel’s Next Move
description: Global equities and oil prices were stable following Iran’s missile and drone attack on Israel, but analysts warn that the calm may not last.
content: Investors are breathing a sigh of relief on Monday. Global stocks are in the green and oil prices have retreated from last week’s gains after Iran’s unprecedented drone and missile attack on Israel was mostly neutralized in the skies. But the calm could be short lived, as world leaders and markets focus on Israel’s response.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Alcorn
title: How to Avoid One of the Deadliest Forms of Skin Cancer
description: We asked experts what to know about melanoma symptoms, treatment and prevention.
content: When spring turns to summer and warm weather lures more people outside, skin cancer may be at most a distant concern. But experts said it’s important to take the risk seriously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein and Joe Rennison
title: Trump Media Stock Plunges 18%, Extending Recent Losses
description: Funds that bet on a fall were set to profit as the parent of Truth Social came under renewed pressure after it registered new shares for a potential sale.
content: Shares of former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company plunged on Monday after the company filed to register the potential sale of tens of millions of additional shares.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Maurice El Medioni, Jewish Algerian Pianist, Dies at 95
description: He fused the music of his Sephardic roots with Arab traditions, incorporating boogie-woogie and other influences, to create a singular style.
content: Maurice El Medioni, an Algerian-born pianist who fused Jewish and Arab musical traditions into a singular style he called “Pianoriental,” died on March 25 in Israel. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: Protesters Block Roads Across the U.S. to Support Those in Gaza
description: The coordinated protests across the United States and around the globe were planned in part to coincide with Tax Day in the United States.
content: Pro-Palestinian protesters shut down traffic Monday morning in cities across the country, part of a global effort to disrupt economies and pressure world leaders to push for a cease-fire in the Gaza Strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky and Krysten Chambrot
title: What’s Your Dinner Party Style? Choose One.
description: Two editors make the case for keeping an at-home event simple or going all-out, with menus to match.
content: Two editors make the case for keeping an at-home event simple or going all-out, with menus to match.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Can You Find the 15 Book Titles Hidden in This Text?
description: This month’s Title Search puzzle challenges you to uncover novels written for middle-grade readers.
content: This month’s Title Search puzzle challenges you to uncover novels written for middle-grade readers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Who Are Key Players in the Trump Manhattan Criminal Trial?
description: The first criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump is underway. Take a closer look at central figures related to the case.
content: The first criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump is underway. Take a closer look at central figures related to the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Interviews by Daniel Bergner
title: Lessons From a 20-Person Polycule
description: How they set boundaries, navigate jealousy, wingman their spouses and foster community.
content: How they set boundaries, navigate jealousy, wingman their spouses and foster community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Larry Buchanan, Karen Hanley and Ruru Kuo
title: Our Reporter on the Problem of New York City Trash
description: Is this how one of the world’s greatest cities still deals with garbage? Larry Buchanan, one of the New York Times reporters who walked miles around the city pondering trash for this story, explains what will be required to take New York’s trash bags off the street.
content: Is this how one of the world’s greatest cities still deals with garbage? Larry Buchanan, one of the New York Times reporters who walked miles around the city pondering trash for this story, explains what will be required to take New York’s trash bags off the street.
source.name: The New York Times
